column5: The relationship between gender, ethnicity, and social support in the adolescent population: Establishing norms for the Student Social Support Scale.
column9: Brown, Kerry A
column10: Brown, Kerry A.: Loyola U Chicago, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.61(4-B), Oct 2000, pp. 2192.
column21: The central purpose of this dissertation was to address both methodological and conceptual issues regarding the assessment of adolescents' perceptions of social support. Specifically, the present study established norms for the adolescent population for the Student Social Support Scale (SSSS; Nolten, 1994). The SSSS has proven to be a sound instrument in measuring children's perceptions of social support, with high levels of reliability and validity. The SSSS measures emotional, informational, appraisal, and instrumental forms of support provided by parents, teachers, close friends, and classmates. Additionally, an exploration of possible ethnic and gender differences was conducted. The research participants of this study consisted of a multiethnic sample of 191 ninth-, tenth-, eleventh-, and twelfth-grade students from four high schools (public and private) in the Chicagoland area. Overall, the preliminary analyses suggested that the SSSS is a valid and reliable measure of perceived social support with a multiethnic sample of adolescents. The results indicate that females consistently reported higher levels of perceived social support across the Total Scale, and Classmate and Close Friend subscales. Conversely, the male subjects consistently reported higher average levels of perceived support on the Parent and Teacher subscales. However, the only statistically significant result was that females perceived higher levels of social support from their Close Friends. With regard to the factor structure of the SSSS (Nolten, 1994), the exploratory factor analysis suggested a four-factor solution (parent, teacher, close friend, classmate). However, the confirmatory factor analysis was unable to confirm such a model. Additionally, the role of ethnicity in social support was inconclusive. That is, statistically, ethnic differences were observed between the five ethnic groups (Caucasian, Latino, African-American, Mixed Ethnicity, and Asian) on the Parent and Teacher subscales. However, due to the fact that the ethnic groups were of unequal size, post hoc analyses, to determine which specific groups differed on these subscales, could not be utilized. Further, Classmate support ratings consistently accounted for a significant proportion of the variance in self-image, social, academic, and total self-concept ratings. Finally, additional analyses indicated that there was not a statistically significant difference between the respondents' age/grade and how they perceived social support from the various sources. Limitations and implications of this study are discussed in the final chapter of this dissertation, and recommendations for social support researchers are provided. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column11: Rovee-Collier, Carolyn [Ed]; Lipsitt, Lewis P [Ed]; Hayne, Harlene [Ed]. (2000). Progress in infancy research, Vol. 1.  (pp. 155-182). xxiv, 314 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
column21: (from the chapter) Argues that facial expression is an important source of information about infant and caregiver behavior, but human observer-based methods of measuring facial expression are semiquantitative, labor intensive, and difficult to standardize across laboratories and over time. When subject recruitment and observational assessments span several years or multiple sites and population, it is difficult to maintain consistent criteria. It is contended that these are serious limiting factors, especially in large, multisite, longitudinal studies. An automated method of facial expression analysis (Automated Face Analysis) that was developed by the authors is discussed. The authors present evidence indicating that the Automated Face Analysis demonstrated high concurrent validity with manual Facial Action Coding System coding, and in the cross-validation set that included subjects of mixed ethnicity, average recognition accuracy for 3 action units ranged from 85-93% depending on the module. It is suggested that with continued development, Automated Face Analysis will greatly reduce or eliminate the need for manual coding, make feasible the use of larger, more representative data sets, and open new areas of investigation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Determinants of ethnic identity among adolescents in Hawai'i.
column9: Greene, William L
column10: Greene, William L.: U Hawaii, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.59(12-A), Jun 1999, pp. 4358.
column21: This study investigated the determinants and salience of ethnic identity among high school students from two neighboring island communities in the State of Hawai'i. Literature has suggested a link between ethnic identity formation and other psychological constructs which may affect school success among some minority groups. This research sought to better understand the values, perceptions, and behaviors related to ethnic identity construction in Hawai'i where every ethnic group is a statistical minority. A mixed-method research design utilized data from 40 student interviews to clarify findings of a survey administered to 580 students from grades 9-12 at two school sites. The survey included the Multigroup Measure of Ethnic Identity. An analysis of variance revealed systematic differences in the salience of ethnic identity across the sample. Rural High scores were significantly higher than the scores of students at Urban High. Scores were higher for females than for males. Within schools, however, scores were higher for single-ethnicity students of a given gender than for mixed ethnicity students of the same gender. Qualitative findings produced examples of cultural resources that students used to explain their ethnic identity, attitudes, and values and provided evidence that females tend to be closer to their ethnic identity than males. The examples also illustrate the role of personal agency in the formation of adolescents' ethnic self-perceptions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Three models of conflict resolution: Effects on intergroup expectancies and attitudes. [References].
column9:
Cross, Susan

Rosenthal, Robert
column10: Cross, Susan: Harvard U, Dept of Psychology, Cambridge, MA, US
column11: Journal of Social Issues. Vol.55(3), Fal 1999, pp. 561-580.
column21: Gordon Allport (1960) once noted that there are many different approaches to conflict resolution, but that few empirical studies have been conducted to examine their effectiveness. This experiment was designed to evaluate the distributive bargaining, integrative bargaining, and interactive problem solving models of conflict resolution, using intergroup expectancies and attitudes as dependent measures. Jewish and Arab students were paired into mixed-ethnicity dyads to discuss the Israeli-Palestinian dispute about Jerusalem according to one of the three models. It was hypothesized that dyad members using the interactive problem solving model would become the least pessimistic about the conflict, and would show the greatest positive change in their attitudes toward members of the other ethnic group. The results support these predictions, and help to make up for the paucity of research on the assessment of conflict resolution strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Culturally related anxiety and ethnic identity in Navajo college students. [References].
column9:
McNeil, Daniel W

Kee, Marvin

Zvolensky, Michael J
column10: McNeil, Daniel W.: West Virginia U, Dept of Psychology, Morgantown, WV, US
column11: Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology. Vol.5(1), Feb 1999, pp. 56-64.
column21: The Cultural Involvement and Detachment Anxiety Questionnaire (D. W. McNeil et al, 1998) and the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure (I. S. Phinney, 1992) were administered to 160 Navajo college students (mean age 25.7 yrs) to explore the relation between ethnic identity and culturally related anxiety, compare level of ethnic identity in reference to standardized samples, and test for gender differences. Correlations indicated a notable lack of relation between ethnic identity and cultural anxiety. This particular Navajo sample evidenced significantly higher levels of ethnic identity in comparison to students of Caucasian, Asian, Hispanic, or mixed ethnicity. There were no significant gender differences in culturally related anxiety. Results are discussed in relation to culturally related anxiety and ethnic identity in the Navajo, with implications for better understanding the nature of cultural anxiety in other American Indians and Alaska Natives. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Research based on mothers and their typically developing children has generally supported the position that maternal directiveness is harmful to a child's cognitive development. The aim of the present study was to determine the role of maternal directiveness on children with developmental delays by comparing maternal scaffolding and directiveness behaviors in relationship to maternal beliefs. Subjects were 25 preschool children with developmental delays and their mothers from a representative urban population of mixed ethnicity and SES. Mother-child dyads were videotaped while engaged in an eight-minute free-play activity and a puzzle task. A questionnaire measuring mothers' beliefs in learning, maturational, and cognitive-developmental theories of development was administered next. Children's developmental ages were later assessed. Tasks were scored using the Mother-Child Rating Scales (MCRS) and the Scales for Assessing Dyadic Scaffolding Behaviors (SADSB). Correlations were run to analyze the relationship between scales. While scores were inconclusive at the subscale level due to high intercorrelations within and among the MCRS and SADSB, important findings resulted including: (a) mothers believed more in a learning theory explanation of development than cognitive-developmental or maturational theories; (b) mothers who believed most in learning theory tended to be more directive in free-play; (c) scaffolding significantly correlated with children's developmental age; (d) directiveness negatively correlated with scaffolding and had little relationship with developmental age; and (e) greater generalizability of the results were obtained than in most previous studies. A framework is suggested for looking at mother-child interaction. Scaffolding provided a better explanation than directiveness for examining mother-child interactions. Suggestions are provided for future research and educational applications of the outcomes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The effects of ethnic identity, ethnicity, and gender on adolescent well-being.
column9:
Martinez, Ruben O

Dukes, Richard L
column10: Martinez, Ruben O.: U Southern Colorado, Pueblo, CO, US
column11: Journal of Youth and Adolescence. Vol.26(5), Oct 1997, pp. 503-516.
column21: Ethnic identity was conceptualized into three categories: (1) unexamined, (2) searching for identity, and (3) achieved ethnic identity. Analyses of data collected from 12,386 adolescents showed that ethnic identity is an important qualifier of the relationships between independent variables of ethnicity and gender, and dependent variables of global self-esteem, academic self-confidence, and purpose in life. Whites and Native Americans had lower ethnic identity, and Blacks and Hispanics had higher ethnic identity. Asians and respondents of mixed ethnicity had intermediate levels of ethnic identity. The greater the ethnic identity, the higher the self-esteem, purpose in life and self confidence. This mechanism applies to ethnic minorities and to women among whom achieved ethnic identity may blunt the negative effects of social denigration and stereotyping, and it applies to whites, too. The paper argues that multiculturalism in the schools can increase ethnic identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Correlates of HIV risk appraisal in women.
column9: Morrison-Beedy, Dianne
column10: Morrison-Beedy, Dianne: Niagara U, Coll of Nursing, Niagara University, NY, US
column11: Annals of Behavioral Medicine. Vol.19(1), Win 1997, pp. 36-41.
column21: Examined the relationship of safer sex behavior practices, knowledge of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), social norms, and familiarity with persons infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) with HIV risk appraisal in women. Risk appraisal was measured by perceived susceptibility and seriousness of AIDS. The AIDS Risk Reduction Model was used to construct a salient framework for this descriptive, correlational survey in which 208 urban women (aged 18-42 yrs) of mixed ethnicity residing in areas with high rates of sexually transmitted diseases/AIDS participated. Findings show that behavior, knowledge, and social norms contributed significant amounts of variance to perceived susceptibility but none of the independent variables contributed significant amounts of variance in perceived seriousness. Overall the findings indicate that risk behaviors are commonly reported, AIDS knowledge is incomplete, and denial of risk is pronounced. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Outward Bound in juvenile corrections: The potential of a superordinate group task in the reduction of imaginary audience preoccupation in violent delinquent youth.
column9: Hunter, George Clyde
column10: Hunter, George Clyde: U Wisconsin - Madison, US
column11: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.57(6-A), Dec 1996, pp. 2371.
column21: A group of approximately 100 adjudicated male delinquent adolescents ages 14-18 attending a court-ordered Outward Bound program in Northern Florida, were examined for resultant changes in levels of self-consciousness. The Imaginary Audience Scale, consisting of two subscales, the Transient Self and the Abiding Self, was administered to half of the subjects pre-treatment, and the other half immediately following their Outward Bound course. Results were analyzed for changes in levels of Imaginary Audience preoccupation over the course of treatment, as well as for ethnic differences in responses to treatment, and in responses to both subscales of the Imaginary Audience Scale. Results showed that participants completing the program, regardless of ethnicity, expressed significantly greater willingness to reveal themselves and take risks in the presence of adults in positions of authority. African American delinquents were less willing to reveal themselves to a mixed-ethnicity audience of peers than Caucasian delinquents, and regardless of ethnicity, the reluctance of all participants to engage in potentially embarrassing behavior in the presence of peers did not improve over the course of treatment. There was no significant interaction found between treatment and ethnicity. Potential implications and reasons for ethnic differences were discussed. The results were interpreted as supporting the use of Outward Bound and similar programs in juvenile corrections as a means to improve adolescent delinquents' willingness to interact with, and accept help from adults in positions of power and authority. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Conducted a follow-up of 59 spouse pairs of Caucasian ancestry, 37 spouse pairs of Japanese ancestry, and 50 spouse pairs of mixed ethnicity who completed a set of personality, social attitude, and language use measures. Spouse correlations were essentially zero for cognitive abilities and low for personality measures, but were substantial for social attitudes and language use. Findings are discussed in terms of the importance of cultural factors in assortative mating. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Use of the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) in a community population of mixed ethnicity: Cultural and linguistic artifacts.
column9:
Escobar, Javier I

Burnam, Audrey

Karno, Marvin

Forsythe, Alan

Landsverk, John

Golding, Jacqueline M
column10: Escobar, Javier I.: U California, VA Medical Ctr, Los Angeles
column11: Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease. Vol.174(10), Oct 1986, pp. 607-614.
column21: Used the MMSE in an epidemiological survey of 3,132 community residents (aged 18+ yrs) of mixed ethnicity (Hispanic, White non-Hispanic) as part of the Los Angeles Epidemiological Catchment Area Program. Results show that age, educational level, ethnicity, and language of the interview influenced the number of MMSE errors. Items on which the effects of ethnicity and language were most pronounced are identified, and suggestions on ways to minimize such sociocultural artifacts are provided in efforts to improve the epidemiological significance of the instrument, particularly as it concerns cross-cultural research. (11 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The predictive validity of each of ten measures of self-concept relative to teachers' ratings of achievement in mathematics and reading of Vietnamese children and of those from five other ethnic groups.
column9:
Oanh, Nguyen T

Michael, William B
column10: Oanh, Nguyen T.: U Southern California
column11: Educational and Psychological Measurement. Vol.37(4), Win 1977, pp. 1005-1016.
column21: For subsamples of 4th- and 6th-grade Vietnamese (26), Caucasian (30), Negro (18), Mexican-American (30), and Asian (non-Vietnamese; 46) pupils as well as for a sample of 29 pupils of mixed ethnicity and for a resulting total sample, differences in mean standing on the Piers-Harris Children's Self-Concept Scale, 3 checklists derived from it and 2 criterion measures of school achievement were examined for statistical significance. In addition to the determination of intercorrelations among the 10 self-concept measures reflecting in part different perceptual frames of reference, validity coefficients were obtained for each subsample between scores on each of the 10 self-concept scales and teachers' ratings of Ss' achievement in mathematics and reading. In general, Ss self-reports about self-concept revealed negligible relationships with teacher ratings, although teacher observations of Ss' self-concepts yielded modest correlations with achievement ratings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
